titleStmt.title: W. B. Davenport et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG4915

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p:
To his Excellency
Thomas. E. Bramlett Governor of Ky.

The undersigned petition Your Excellency to remit the fine adjudged against George Alfred of fifty dollars for selling whiskey to a slave. They state that they were of the jury and heard the testimony. And that they think it ought to be remitted. That the said Alfred is a good loyal citizen_ is a man of sobriety and property_ and that the prosecution would never have been had except for an unfortunate misunderstanding between him and the prosecutor_ and as in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray &c

W. B. Davenport
J Haselden
C. T. Kearby
L. D. Atkins
J C England
H Z Perkins
Of the Jury
J H Davis
E. Y. Holsclaw
Alfred Boner
Thos. S. Moore
A T Prior

Hon Thomas E Bramlett
Frankfort Ky

I respectfully state to your Excellency that the signers of the within petition were members of the Jury that tried the case of the commonwealth against George W. Alford for selling Whisky to slave and that the accompanying paper is a true copy of the Warrant in said case, I further state that said case was tried before me as J. P. Garrard county Ky in the town of Bryanstville on the last Friday in April 1864 and that the statements of the within petitioners are wholly true. This 24 day of May 1864

Jas M Philips
Justice of the Peace
G.C

I respectfully state to Gov. Thos. E. Bramlette that I was the executive officer of Justices court that tried the case of the Commonwealth agt G. W. Alford for selling whisky to a slave as refered to in the within petition, and join with the within petitioners in requesting your Excellency to remit the fine agt said Alford
